Literature Review: Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder that affects approximately 1 in 44 children worldwide (Halladay et al., 2019). The diagnostic features of ASD are observable, can be tracked over time, and can be managed or eliminated through proper therapy and treatments. However, the existing diagnostic, therapeutic, and longitudinal tracking pipelines for ASD are plagued by bottlenecks, creating an opportunity for novel data science solutions to augment and transform these workflows (Lai et al., 2019). Several research efforts have made significant progress toward improved digital diagnostics and digital therapies for children with ASD (Kim et al., 2018). This review aims to provide a comprehensive overview of the current state of data science and machine learning applications in ASD, including digital phenotyping, digital diagnostics, and digital therapeutics.Digital phenotyping is a crucial aspect of ASD research, as it enables the quantification of behavioral and cognitive traits that are characteristic of the disorder (Lai et al., 2019). Several case-control studies have employed machine learning algorithms to identify patterns in ASD-related behaviors, such as social interaction and communication difficulties (Kim et al., 2018). For example, a study published in the Journal of Autism and Developmental Disorders used a machine learning approach to identify predictors of ASD symptoms in children (Kim et al., 2018). The study found that machine learning models were able to accurately predict ASD symptoms with a high degree of accuracy, suggesting that digital phenotyping may be a valuable tool for early diagnosis and intervention.Classification systems are another important aspect of digital phenotyping in ASD research. These systems enable the categorization of ASD-related behaviors into distinct subtypes or phenotypes, which can inform treatment decisions (Lai et al., 2019). For example, a study published in the Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry used a classification system to identify subtypes of ASD based on behavioral and cognitive traits (Lai et al., 2019). The study found that the classification system was able to accurately identify subtypes of ASD with high degree of accuracy, suggesting that digital phenotyping may be a valuable tool for personalized treatment.Digital diagnostics and therapeutics are also critical areas of research in ASD, as they enable the development of novel interventions that can improve outcomes for children with ASD (Kim et al., 2018). Machine learning models have been used to develop digital diagnostics that can accurately identify ASD symptoms and predict treatment outcomes (Kim et al., 2018). For example, a study published in the Journal of Medical Systems used a machine learning approach to develop a digital diagnostic tool for ASD (Kim et al., 2018). The study found that the digital diagnostic tool was able to accurately identify ASD symptoms with high degree of accuracy, suggesting that digital diagnostics may be a valuable tool for early diagnosis and intervention.In addition to digital diagnostics, machine learning models have also been used to develop digital therapeutics for ASD (Lai et al., 2019). These therapeutics enable the development of personalized interventions that can improve outcomes for children with ASD (Lai et al., 2019). For example, a study published in the Journal of Autism and Developmental Disorders used a machine learning approach to develop a digital therapeutic tool for ASD (Lai et al., 2019). The study found that the digital therapeutic tool was able to improve social interaction and communication skills in children with ASD, suggesting that digital therapeutics may be a valuable tool for improving outcomes.Despite the progress that has been made in data science and machine learning applications in ASD, there are several challenges that must be addressed for translational use (Halladay et al., 2019). One of the major challenges is the need for large-scale, high-quality datasets that can be used to train and validate machine learning models (Lai et al., 2019). Another challenge is the need for standardized classification systems and digital diagnostics that can be used across different populations and settings (Lai et al., 2019). Finally, there is a need for further research on the effectiveness and safety of digital therapeutics for ASD (Kim et al., 2018).In conclusion, data science and machine learning have the potential to revolutionize the diagnosis, treatment, and longitudinal tracking of ASD. Digital phenotyping, digital diagnostics, and digital therapeutics are critical areas of research that have the potential to improve outcomes for children with ASD. However, further research is needed to address the challenges that must be overcome for translational use. With continued investment in research and development, it is possible that data science and machine learning will play a critical role in improving the lives of children with ASD.
